There has been an overall improvement in capacities as evidenced by 35 percentage points increase over the baseline The total score has surpassed the target except for slight shortfalls in systemic capacities These are in the areas of i formulation of policies and plans and ii engaging and building consensus Please see below

description.narrative:
Expansion of the terrestrial PA estate
increased areas of KBAs under legal protection
new governance types in new conservation areas recognized as part of the national PA system
program for accelerated expansion of PA system

comment.narrative:
59 terrestrial PAs covering 26 million hectares
New PAs are established only through the NIPAS process
No program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PAs to cover new conservation areas

Additional 9 terrestrial PAs covering 400000 hectares bringing the total area of KBA under protection to 3 million hectares
At least three new governance types IP LGU and local community managed conservation areas recognized by Executive fiat as part of national PA system
Program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PA system to include new conservation areas within KBAs developed and ready for implementation

Partially Achieved Since Project start a total of 46 PAsLCAs and ICCAs covering 400724 hectares of KBAs have been added to the countrys protected area system
3 PAs covering 174549 hectares
26 LCAs from NewCAPP covering 80163 hectares
10 ICCAs from NewCAPP covering 68179 hectares 3 ICCAs registered at UNEPWCMC
1 LCA in BPP site Mt Hamiguitan 3784 hectares
5 ICCAs recognized through FPE and PTFCF covering 73002 hectares
1 ICCA registered at UNEPWCMC from non NewCAPP sites 1047 hectares
This brings to 3007009 hectares the total area of KBAs under protection
The Senate has passed on Second Reading the Enhanced NIPAS Bill seeking to legislate 97 PAs and strengthen NIPAS provisions including recognition of ICCAs within PAs Of these 92 are existing PAs with Presidential Proclamations while 5 are new PAs that will form part of the national PA estate Once approved the Bill will strengthen the legal status of these nationally legislated PAs under the NIPAS In all these 97 PAs cover 267483068 hectares and an additional of 179 43960 hectares of buffer zones in all 59 are within KBA
Based on various presentations and advocacies an additional 33 LGUs and 209 IP organizations have expressed interest to establish LCAs and document their ICCAs respectively
GIZPAME is supporting LCAs and ICCAs in the establishment of 100 new sites terrestrial and marine PAs in KBAs
Based on NewCAPPs lessons and experiences a medium sized GEF proposal has been developed to strengthen policy and capacities for ICCA recognition in the Philippines to cover an additional 10 sites with estimated total coverage of 118000 hectares
NewCAPP spearheaded the preparation of a National PA System Master Plan that will guide the expansion of the Philippines PA estate based on the following criteria i representativeness comprehensiveness and balance ii adequacy iii coherence and complementarity iv consistency and v cost effectiveness efficiency and equity The Plan recognizes LCAs ICCAs and other effective area based conservation measures OECMs as part of the National PA System
Only two new modalities were developed under the Project The Project was not able to find a workable model on communitymanaged CA In lieu of this the Project tried to investigate the viability of a privatelymanaged CA But this did not progress as well But the 2 models LCA and ICCA proved to be very viable option in expanding the protected area system
On the policy while no executive fiat was secured to support LCA and ICCA the project was able to influence Environment Management Bureau EMB to consider these as environmentally critical areas compelling other development activities such as mining to undertake fullblown impact assessment The project was also able to draft a number of supportive policies and turned over to BMB One of which was the ICCA Bill which was passed in the Committee level in both houses of Congress
Both Congress and Senate have approved at Committee level the Draft ICCA Bill KBAs LCAs and ancestral domain lands are now considered as environmentally critical areas ECAs per Memorandum Circular of the Environmental Management Bureau on the Revised Procedures for the Philippines EIA System

While the Project was not able to meet the end of target level there has been improvement in PA Financing scores in all aspects by a total of 21 percentage points compared to the baseline While the Project has accomplished all outputs under Outcome 3 more needs to be done to improve capacity for system wide financing such as formulation and implementation of PA Business Plan The results of the PA Financing Study has been translated into a Guide However BMB has to roll this out to the rest of the PAs These requirements are being put together under the PA System Master Plan

description.narrative: Habitat range of 109 globally threatened species in 9 pilot sites protected

comment.narrative: Expected to decrease by at least 10 per year
Increase by 200

Achieved The habitat of 186 globally threatened in 14 project sites within 10 KBAs are now protected by the local government units local and indigenous cultural communities through the establishments of 24 LCAs and recognition of 10 ICCAs Below is the summary
27 critically endangered 1 reptilia 6 aves 1 mamalia 19 magnoliopsida
34 endangered 3 amphibia 15 aves 4 mamalia 11 magnoliopsida 1 coniferopsida
125 vulnerable 21 amphibia 8 reptilia 39 aves 9 mamalia 48 magnoliopsida
1threatened species 1 aves Hypothymis helenae
However please take note that during the biodiversity assessment and resource inventory conducted in the project sites a total of 309 species were recorded and have not been classified yet but are deemed locally importantsignificant The breakdown of these species are as follow
12 amphibia
50 reptilia
82 aves
25 mamalia
136 magnoliopsida
4 coniferopsida
These data may be taken as baseline information and partial list of species A more comprehensive study must be undertaken especially in ICCA areas as the inventory in most sites were limited to flora However conduct of such study should be approved by the IP community and the design should allow them to take greater responsibility or at least encourage active participation
In addition there are 133 species 10 amphibia 14 reptilia 82 aves 21 mamalia 6 magnoliopsida considered as least concern
In Mt Nacolod BD assessment 2 new species of frogs were discovered and 5 species 2 amphibia and 3 mamalia were considered new island record

description.narrative: Management Effectiveness in PAs and new conservation areas

comment.narrative: Average of 35 in all nine sites

Increase in METT scores in pilot sites by an average of at least 20 compared to baseline levels
METT scorecard applied in all PAs and new CAs as basis for supporting capacity development and implementing adaptive management

Achieved Average METT Scores of NewCAPP sites increased by 31 points or 83 from the average baseline score of 37
Overall the increase in the METT scores can be attributed to the generation of information in the process of establishing LCA and documentation and recognition of ICCA These information improved the planning process and identification and provided bases for issuing local resolutions for the establishmentrecognition of conservation areas There was also improvement in the monitoring system Also in general there was improvement in the condition of the important values in the CA Lastly the community is slowly reaping economic benefits
At the systemic level BMB is routinely applying METT scorecard in all PAs

comment.narrative:
IPAF annual allocations legislated through General Appropriations Act
US 298 Million

Increase in IPAF collections by 25 or to a level of US 373 Million

As of March 2015 total IPAF collections USD 779 Million This represents an increase of 161

description.narrative: National level capacity to manage financing of the PA system

comment.narrative: Limited capacity by PAWB to manage financing for national PA system
PAWB has improved capacity to use new tools and mechanisms to sustainably manage financing of national terrestrial PA system to include new CAs

Achieved
Draft Addendum to DENR Administratve Order No 200717 on the Rules and Regulations Governing Special Uses within Protected Areas SAPA NewCAPP commissioned a study on SAPA fees being collected in PAs in 2011 to establish a common methodology in computing SAPA fees across all PAs A recommendation to increase fees from SAPA using market values of properties thereby potentially increasing internally generated revenues across all PAs was presented and discussed with PAWB and DENR Undersecretary These recommendations were translated into a draft Addendum to the existing Department Administrative Order DAO for the following objectives
To provide premium to ecosystem services provided by PAs eg water production which are limited resources
To generate revenues which can be utilized for improved management and operations of the protected area thereby decreasing required national government subsidy
To serve as a regulatory tool or disincentive for increased resource uses beyond the carryingcapacities of PAs and
To increase local economic opportunities eg increased local employment from ecotourism establishments
Recommendations for maximizing the potentials offered by existing financing instruments A review of Department Administrative Order 200051 or the policy on PA user fees was undertaken to conduct an inventory of user fees being collected in three PAs namely Mt Apo Natural Park Mt Kanlaon Natural Park and Mt Kitanglad Natural Park constraints on not being able to maximize potentials of user fees and recommendations on improving PA financing The study recommended i improvement in implementation of DAO 200051 and ii promotion of other sustainable financing mechanisms
Increased understanding of Integrated Protected Area Fund IPAF management and disbursment process of PA staff A review of IPAF collections procedures and status of all 240 PAs was undertaken by the Project A Technical Brief was prepared summarizing the findings and disseminated to DENR audiences and other stakeholders A total of 120 PAs from 200 participants attended the training in 2012 while 353 participants from 131 PAs attended the IPAF training in 2015
Defined procedures and accountability centers in implementation of RA 10629 NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB in developing the implementing guidelines of Republic Act 10629 or An Act Providing for the Retention by PAMB of 75 of Revenues accruing to IPAF Amending for the Purpose Section 16 of RA 7586 known as NIPAS Act of 1992 Signed in September 26 2013 RA 10629 provides for retention of 75 of PA income at PAMB level To set operational procedures on how RA 10629 would have to be implemented by PAs NewCAPP assisted BMB in working with DBMBureau E and BTrNCAD in crafting the DENRDBM Joint Memorandum Circular JMC 20141 which was signed in September 26 2014 by Secretary Paje of DENR Secretary Abad of DBM with Congressman Teves as key witness
Improved collaboration among donorfunded Projects providing technical assistance to the Bureau on financing NewCAPP convened the PA Financing FAPs Thematic Group where an agreement is reached to work together on PA Financing Roadmap The National PA Financing Roadmap which intends to provide overall direction and strategy for sustaining financing of PAs and other conservation areas was included in the PA System Master Plan component

description.narrative: Number of PAsCAs using new tools and mechanisms for sustainable financing

comment.narrative: Nil
Additional PAsCAs benefit from use of learning manual revised policies and replication of sustainable financing tools and mechanisms for PACA management

Achieved
18 PAs benefitted from technical assistance in the enhancement of management plans preparation of Business Plans and identification of specific financing mechanisms
The two waves of IPAF trainings 2012 and 2015 benefitted 300 participants from 131 PAs through IPAF retention policies and sharing of successful mechanisms to raise PA financing The IPAF Handbook will benefit all PAs

description.narrative: Number of sites with capacities for financing business planning and cost effective management

comment.narrative: Nil
At least 3 new PACAs have capacities for site level financing business planning and cost effective management

Achieved
A PA business planning process was rolledout in eighteen selected PAs through Sustainable Financing of Protected Areas Project of WBGEF NSPENRMP NewCAPP developed the Terms of Reference of this Project and heavily supported PAWB in the procurement process and implementation of the said Project Following the business planning process introduced by REECS the Projects contractor NewCAPP documented the process and integrated it in the LCA Guide developed and published by the Project The business planning module was also demonstrated in Mt Nacolod in Southern Leyte and Mts Nugas and Lantoy in Cebu as part of the LCA management planning process

description.narrative: Awareness and support from stakeholders for national PA system

comment.narrative:
Limited awareness and support as evidenced by
i only 10 legislations passed to date
ii limited amount of IPAF US 298 Million
iii high degree of threat of KBAs
iv high degree of threat of major biogeographic zones from infrastructure development

Increased awareness and support as evidenced by
i additional legislations passed to legalize establishment of more PAs and inclusion of CAs in the system
ii increased funding support from various sources
iii reduction in levels of destructive activities and
iv number of proposed development projects rejected for being incompatible with PA and CA management objectives

Achieved
Proposed Legislations The proposed PA Omnibus Bill will strengthen the legal status of 97 proclaimed PAs into full gazzetted PAs covering 26 Million hectares and 179439 hectares of buffer zones The Enhanced NIPAS Bill also contains a provision recognizing ICCAs within PAs Congressman Baguilat also filed an ICCA Bill in Congress followed by Senator Legarda at the Senate The bill was approved by the Committee level Next step coordinate with the Committee Secretariat for the Plenary Discussions
Funding Support from Various Sources Since NewCAPP started in 2009 additional projects were implemented in the sector with an estimated total funding commitment of USD 519 M These are
UNDPGEFBPP USD 45 M
GIZPAME USD 99M
USAIDBWISER USD 25 M
UNDPGEFMKBA USD 8 M
UNDPGEFSGP USD 45M
Legislative Support With ASoG a briefing with Congress on the Second State of the PA Report was held on October 28 2014 Those who attended the presentation expressed support to additional funding and the passage of the Omnibus Bill on PAs
Reduction in Levels of Destructive Activities The LCA Management Plans and ICCACCPs specify that there will be no destructive activities that will be allowed in these areas EMB Memorandum Circular 005 dated July 2014 Revised Guidelines for Coverage Screening and Standardized Requirements under the Philippines EIS System has categorized LCAs and ancestral domains as environmentally critical areas
In Mt Hilonghilong the MGB representative requested a copy of the shape files of the ICCA site to designate it as no go zone for mining
Number of proposed development projects rejected for being incompatible with PA and CA management objectives 11 of NewCAPP sites have clearly stated in their managementconservation plans the prohibition of extractivedestructive activities within the conservation areas such mining LGUs have likewise issued support policies such as
Polillo SB Resolutions nos 119 2012 0692011 reiterated their strong opposition to mining and quarrying operations and similar activities within their jurisdiction
Mt Nacolod the Provincial Board issued Resolution No 740s2012 which disallows any form of mining activity in the LCA
In BBNP the strength and unity of the tribe and community prevented the operation of CelloPhil and saved the forest CelloPhil established pulp and paper processing plant in the 70s threatening the lush forests of BBNP The main reason behind the resistance was the Bodong or traditional resources management in the area Since then no extractive activity has threatened the area The Bodong and Lapat highlighted the ICCA and CCP of the Banao and Balatoc Tribe
Nug as Palinpinon In 2013 there was an incident of clearing in some parts of the Argao forests by the LGU for tourism purposes However this was immediately arrested upon the knowledge of the DENR Regional Office of Region 7 and a case was already filed in court to address the incident
IEC Support for the 2 National Conferences Case stories from NewCAPP sites prepared and distributed during the First National LCA Conference and Second National ICCA Conference held in October 2014 New exhibit panels on ICCA and LCA were prepared and launched during the conferences
PMU also supported DENR Region 10 in the development of IEC materials for its 1st Protected Area Conference on July 2223 2014
The NewCAPP website has been continuously updated with latest project activities and technicalproject reports From October 2011June 2015 the average website daily hits is 1237 the monthly average is 37381 Since the website was established in October 2011 it has generated a total of 168 million hits by the end of June 2015

description.narrative: Capacities for M and E

comment.narrative: Weak for existing PAs no M and E protocols for new conservation areas
PAWB and local PACA Managers and staff have capacities to undertake M and E and use this information for adaptive management

Achieved
NewCAPP carried out a review of implementation of BMS in August 2013 which identified a set of recommendations for improvement These were taken on by the Wildlife Resources Division In addition the GIZPAME is supporting the development of cost effective BD baseline and monitoring methods that consider the recommendation of the earlier NewCAPP study and the competency standards for PA sector
NIPAS PA M and E system drafted A discussion with BMB Senior Staff and other FAPs was held to review the NIPAS Program and the revised NIPAS M and E indicators and reference sheets These will be integrated in the M and E System of the PA System Master Plan

description.narrative: Incorporation of BD conservation goals in local plans

comment.narrative: Isolated efforts only by a few PAMBs and NGO partners

ADSDPP 4 BBNP ZMR Mts Iglit Baco Mts Irid Angelo and Binuang
Resource management plans of local communities 2 Nug as Lantoy Hilong hilong
LGU land use and development plans 3 Tawi tawi Mt Nacolod and Polilio islands

Achieved
In BBNP the ICCAs of the Banao IP community has been declared by the LGU of Balbalan as conservation areas in the updating of their CLUP
In the case of Balatoc IP community the CCP is being prepared following completion of the resource inventory
In the Zambales Mountain Range The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Mangatarem LGU has been adopted by the Council and endorsed to DENR for confirmation The Plan was developed to be consistent with the Forest Land Use Plan FLUP of the municipality
The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Palauig LGU for Mt Tapulao has been completed and adopted by the Council The Plan includes the entire forest land of the municipality and therefore also represent the FLUP
The ICCA and CCP of Aeta Abellen in Maporac Zambales has been incorporated in the updated ADSDPP of the IP community
The ICCA documentation of Aeta IP community in San Felipe Zambales Mountain Range has been completed and the CCP is up for validation by the community
In Mt Iglit Baco PA the CCP of the Buhid Bangon Mangyan IP community has been completed and incorporated in the updated ADSDPP The PA Management Plan for the Iglit Baco is due for development where the ICCA and CCP will form an integral part
In Mt Irid Angelo the ICCA documentation and its CCP are incorporated in the ADSDPP of the Dumagat Remontados IP community
The LGUs of Argao Alcoy and Dalaguete have each prepared their LCA Management Plan consistent with the goals and objectives of the Nug as Palinpinon Corridor In Argao the LCA Management Plan is also incorporated in the enhanced Forest Land Use Plan FLUP In Alcoy and Dalaguete the FLUP has been prepared prior to NewCAPP but it was ensured that the LCA Plan is consistent with their FLUPs In each of these LGUs the Municipal Councils have issued Resolutions adopting the LCA Management Plan
In Mt Hilong hilong the CCP has been incorporated in the ADSDPP of the MamanwaManobo IP community
In Tawitawi the LCA management plan was adopted by the LGU and budget for its implementation was integrated in the 2015 Annual Investment Plan of the LGU
In Mt Nacolod the LCA Management Framework was prepared and adopted by the seven 7 Municipal LGUs and Provincial Council
In the Polillo Group of Islands the municipalities of Polillo Burdeos and Panukulan who are among the first municipalities to establish LCAs have already integrated the LCA Management Plans in their CLUPs and are already updating their plans at present
In the case of Mt Kalatungan the ICCA and CCP have been adopted by the Protected Area Management Board PAMB The updated PA Management Plan of Mt Kalatungan Natural Park dedicates a section on management of ancestral domains within the PA

description.narrative: Operational Manual for local management bodies

comment.narrative: Inadequate for use by existing PAMBs no Manual yet for local management bodies of new conservation areas
Operational Manuals are implemented to strengthen capacities of local management bodies of existing PAs and new conservation areas

Achieved
The Handbook for PAMB Operations and the accompanying training modules has been submitted and is now undergoing final review The BMB will take on the roll out of the manual and training modules once finalized

description.narrative: PA system of the Philippines has been expanded under new and diverse management regimes ancestral domain local government and community managed areas to cover an additional 400000 hectares of Key Biodiversity Areas KBAs and with enhanced potential for further expansion
Coverage of the national PA system in terms of governance types

comment.narrative: Limited to PAs established through the NIPAS process managed by PAMBs only
Coverage of national PA system is expanded to include new conservation areas under diverse governance types IP LGU and local community managed areas

Achieved The Project has established two new modalities LCA and ICCA for expanding and diversifying the national protected area system The BMB has adopted these and are being mainstreamed into the National PA System Master Plan A Bill on ICCA was approved at the Committee level in both Houses of Congress An Omnibus Bill that intends to legislate 97 PAs is also filed in Congress It includes provisions on recognition of ICCA As transitory mechanism BMB Technical Bulletins on ICCA and LCA were prepared and undergoing final review These specify the applicable policies to support requests for ICCA recognition and LCA establishment and encourage field offices to provide support
At the site level a total of 148342 hectares were designated as conservation areas For ICCA three sites Mt Kalatungan httpwwwiccaregistryorgensites27 Ayta Abellen tribe in Cabangan Zambales httpwwwiccaregistryorgensites28 and Hilong hilong httpwwwiccaregistryorgensites31 have completed the entire process of documentation and are now registered at UNEPWCMC ICCA Registry Two additional sites Banao tribe in BBNP Kalinga Watershed and Buhid and Bangon tribes in Mts Iglit Baco KBA have both submitted their ICCA documentation and in the process of providing the additional information requested by UNEPWCMC The Balatoc tribe in Kalinga Watershed is in the final stages of the documentation and recognition process By the end of the year it is expected that an additional 11000 hectares of ICCA will be included in the ICCA registry The Dumagat Remontados in Mt Irid Angelo KBA has yet to conduct resource inventory in the identified ICCA sites to enrich available information Once completed the ICCA case study will be prepared and submitted to UNEPWCMC However community declaration of ICCA has been completed and its CCP and ICCA have been integrated in the ADSDPP of Dumagat Remontado which was prepared in parallel with the ICCA documentation For Ayta Abellen tribe in San Felipe Zambales the implementation was put on hold since 2014 due to internal conflicts among IP leaders within the tribe IKSP documentation on resource management and governance resource inventory CCP have been completed However the CCP needs to be validated and the case study has to be prepared
For LCA sites the management plans were completed LGU funding for initial implementation have been allocated and all sites have secured policies to formalize the establishment of LCAs Mangatarem and Mt Tapulao both in Zambales KBA have established LCAs as critical habitats Mangatarem has submitted their critical habitat management plans to the Office of the DENR Secretary for the issuance of Department Order Mt Tapulao is packaging the plan for submission also to DENR Both LGUs have issued resolutions adopting the LCA In Polillo Group of Islands a total of 10329 hectares of conservation area were strengthenedestablished under the Project A draft PGI Biodiversity Conservation Strategic Action Plan was prepared in 2012 to support LCA The three municipalities Alcoy Argao and Dalaguete covering Mts Nug as and Lantoy KBA have agreed to establish the Nug as Palinpinon Biodiversity Corridor with a total area of 9649 hectares Each LGU has prepared and adopted a management plan In Mt Nacolod in Southern Leyte the LCA Management Framework was adopted by the Provincial LGU through a Resolution This Framework was turned over to the PLGU last June 29 2015 during the environmental submit organized by the provincial government It has 40860 hectares within 7 municipalities in So Leyte and Leyte The PLGU also issued a resolution declaring Mt Nacolod as Forest Protected Area in 2012 In Bud Bongao in Tawi Tawi a Provincial Ordinance declaring 325 hectares of Bud Bongao Peak was issued in 2013 A Management Plan was also prepared and budget has been allocated for its implementation

description.narrative: Extent of the national terrestrial PA system in proportion to total area of the country

comment.narrative: Achieved 01 percent or 3007009 hectares This represents an additional of 400724 hectares from the baseline of 26 million hectares The target was to increase the coverage of the protected area within KBAs to 3 million hectares or 10 of the total area of the country NewCAPP contributed 148342 hectares or 37 of the additional areas established over the course of the ProjectDuring the Project another PA outside of KBA was established covering 26125 hectares Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscapeunder Proclamation Number 296 signed on November 24 2012

description.narrative: Program for expansion and diversification of national PA system

comment.narrative: None
Expansion and diversification of the national PA system is guided by a 5 year program

Achieved Further expansion and diversification of the national PA system shall be guided by the Master Plan which is an ongoing effort supported by various projectsdonors The Plan recognizes LCAs ICCAs and OECMs as part of the national PA system
The National Program Framework for ICCAs is contained in the Manila Declaration which was produced from the First National ICCA Consortium in 2012
Following the Declaration the Project supported the establishment of the Philippine ICCA Consortium Founded in February 2013 the Consortium adopted the name Bukluran ng mga Katutubo para sa Pangangalaga ng Kalikasan sa Pilipinas BUKLURAN While still in its nascent stage it is actively participating in the discussions on ICCA at the national level
With the BUKLURAN the Project coordinated with the Office of Cong Baguilat in the development of the ICCA Bill It was passed at the Committee level of the House of Representatives in December 2014 A counterpart bill was filed by Sen Loran Legarda in the Senate in February 2015 and was passed also at the Committee level in March 2015
NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB and UNDPPhilippines in the formulation of a new project on ICCA with the BUKLURAN UNDP NCIP PAFID and KASAPI The project document was completed and submitted to GEF headquarters in May 2015
In October 2014 the BMBNewCAPP in partnership with NCIP BUKLURAN and many organizations organized the 2nd National Conference on ICCA to assess progress of ICCA institutionalization in the country and implementation of the Manila Declaration output of the first national conference The Conference became a venue to share best practices and the support to ICCA was solidified Different organizations from the government private sector and nongovernment organization committed to support the strengthening of ICCA in the country It was also used to enhance the ADSDPP Guidelines and include the identification and documentation of ICCAs This will usher a systemic and more systematic process Along with BMB the Conference was cofunded by PTFCF GIZ and UNDPPhilippines
With enough lessons and experience on the ground on establishing local conservation area the Project together with several organizations also conducted the First National Conference on LCA Around 250 individuals from the LGUs NGAs NGOs academe private sector and development organizations attended the conference The Conference was able to consolidate support from all sectors on LCA and have increased buy in from DILG HLURB and local chief executives During the Conference a Resolution was issued by the participants urging national government agencies to strengthen support to LGUs and upscale the establishment of LCAs This Resolution will be incorporated in the PA System Master Plan being developed
Guides on the documentation and recognition of ICCA and establishment of LCA were finalized The LCA Guide was launched with DILG and HLURB in 2015 The ICCA Sourcebook is for printing after incorporating comments from Global ICCA Consortium

Partially Achieved At the time of design it was thought that the Project will be able to place the entire KBA landscape under new conservation status However the reality is KBAs comprise expansive landscapes which include patches of alienable and disposable lands cultivated agriculture forest plantations and other land uses Thus the identification of new conservation areas was guided by BD assessments to determine the extent and location of areas that should be conserved negotiations with local partners and stakeholders to engender ownership and support As a result the areas placed under conservation status LCAs and ICCAs represent only a portion 37 of the total area of pilot KBAs of NewCAPP
Greater Luzon BZ 5302 An additional 23 protected areas 15 LCAs and 8 ICCAs establishedrecognized since project start with a total of 99939 hectares
Mindoro BZ 5822 With the recognition of 3 ICCAs of the Buhid and BangonTribes in Mts Iglit Baco KBA and 1 ICCA of the Mangyan Tagabukid the total coverage of protected area under protection increased to 136224 hectares against 233590 hectares of KBA
Greater Negros Panay BZ 4952 3 LCAs comprising the Nugas Lantoy BD Corridor was established under the Project The total area designated for conservation is 9649 hectares bringing the total coverage to 167929 hectares
Greater Mindanao BZ 3852 A total of 133135 hectares were established from the proclamation of 2 PAs establishment of 7LCAs and recognition of 5 ICCA thereby increasing the coverage to 1023897 hectares
Sulu BZ 2949 The Project was able to establish 1 LCA in Bud Bongao contributing 325 hectares to the 9421 hectares baseline

description.narrative: Number of hectares in production landscapes waterscapes under sustainable management

comment.narrative: No increase during the period

At least additional 10000 hectares under sustainable management but not yet certified
At least additional 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards

A total of 128138 hectares have been identified and classifiedzoned as sustainable use management areas The classificationzonation of these areas was part of the mainstreaming of biodiversity in the local land use plans of the LGUs in the eight demonstration sites The sustainable use management areas shall be developed and managed to improve the land productivity to support agricultural production and agribased livelihood opportunities through sustainable upland management strategies and land and water use conservation These sustainable use management areas coverage are as follows
Quirino Nagtipunan and Maddela31124 hectares
Cagayan 60936 hectares Calatrava Negros Occidental 2362 hectares
Taytay Palawan 33716 hectares
The additional 10000 hectares that will be subject to certification will be specified from these areas delineated as sustainable use management zones
To date about 1209 hectares in the eight project sites were assessed and documented as potential sites of farm areas practicing biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices These areas upon initial assessment meet the standards of biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices Further assessment and documentation of the areas will be done upon once DENR and DA approve the policy standards and certifications schemes for biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices is obtained from DENR and DA
The standards for biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices have been drafted and would be finalized following approval of the Joint Administrative Order of DA and DENR on the promotion of BDfriendly agricultural practices in PAs and KBAs and wider agricultural landscape is issued Subsequently the BPPPMU will discuss with DA Team strategies to meet the target of at least 800 hectares and 8 production systems under certified production practices that meet sustainability and biodiversity standards

description.narrative: Population estimates of at least three critically endangered species in three demonstration sites

comment.narrative: Expected to decrease by at least 10 by endproject
No decline in populations of tamaraw in Siburan forests Visayan hornbill in Central Panay and NNNP and Philippine eagle in Mt Hamiguitan

Mt Siburan in the municipality of Sablayan in the province of Mindoro Occidental is part of the habitat range of the Tamaraw that includes the adjoining Mt Aruyan Malati also in Sablayan and nearby Mt IglitBaco in Mindoro Oriential Tamarraw used to be abundant throughout the island of Mindoro numbering around 10000 in the 1900s The most recent Tamaraw count by DENRTamaraw Conservation Program TCP April 2013 recorded 345 individuals but count stations were mostly concentrated on the southwestern portion of Mts IglitBaco
The 2004 survey by Haribon Foundation in Mt Siburan reported tracks and fecal evidence of the species along the banks of Malate River The TCP survey in Mt AruyanMalati estimated that around 11 tamaraw individuals were in the area According to TCP there is no official report confirming the presence of tamaraa in Mt Siburan for some anecdotal records sometime in year 2000 regarding the presence of a Tamaraw bull in the area The 2013 survey in Aruyan recorded ethnobiological data but failed to locate any physical evidence of the presence of the species in Mt Siburan An ethnobiodiversity survey currently is beind conducted by Haribon the BPP site partner to determine the number of tamaraws in Mt Siburan
The biodiversity survey in Central Panay Mountains CPM in 2014 validated the presence of Visayan hornbill in CPM The biodiversity study conducted in Northern Negros Natural Park NNNP counted 14 Visayan Tarictic Hornbill and 3 Rufous headed hornbill in the area
The biodiversity assessment conducted in selected sampling sites within in Mt Hamiguitan confirmed the presence of a Philippine Eagle in Barangay Surop The eagle is probably Cabuaya the chick of the eagles Cabu and Aya of Mati due to the green leg band and attached transmitter

The BDSEA has gone through several consultations with the Technical Review Committee of BMB This was also presented and discussed with key National Economic and Development Authority NEDA officers and staff for possible issuance of an Executive Order for adoption and governmentwide use of BDSEA

description.narrative: Programmes and policies to support biodiversity friendly agricultural production in critical landscapes

comment.narrative:
No agrobiodiversity programs in AFMA plan
National Action Plan for Sustainable Land management NAPSLM do not include agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs and KBAs
Standards and certification schemes limited to organic agricultural production
Activities to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

Updated AFMA Plan incorporates agrobiodiversity programs
Revised NAPSLM includes agrobiodiversity projects in buffer zones of PAs or KBAs
Standards and certification system for biodiversity friendly production systems in place
Policy and program developed in DA to promote conservation and utilization of indigenous crops

The Department of Agriculture DA has proposed that instead of updating the AFMA plan a Joint Administrative Order be promulgated because the updating of the AFMA Plan is not being done on a yearly basis Furthermore the AFMA covers the wider agricultural landscapes that covers various stakeholders while the area of focus for mainstreaming biodiversity will be within and around the Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas The request was reflected in a DA letter to the DENR dated July 2014 The DADENR Joint Administrative Order Mainstreaming BiodiversityFriendly Agricultural Practices In and Around Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas and Promoting the Same in Wider Agricultural Landscapes is subject to parallel review of DENR Policy Technical Working Group PTWG and DA Policy Review Committee
The draft National Action Plan for Sustainable Land Management NAPSLM has been prepared which provides for robust discussion on biodiversity The concern on biodiversity is part of the Strategic Objective 2 of NAPSLM To regenerate and rehabilitate watershed landscapes and their resources for ecosystem services enhancement The NAPSLM also incorporates two 2 subprograms of the Thematic Program 3 Watershed Landscape Management and Rehabilitation includes biodiversity as follows 1 Sustainable management of forest resources and 2 Promotion of SLM for forest resources conservation and management It also include the listings of completed and ongoing projects on biodiversity in buffer zones of Protected Areas and Key Biodiversity Areas
The said draft NAPSLM is being reviewed by Department of Agriculture and targeted for approval by end of 2015
Drafted the Philippine National Standard for BiodiversityFriendly Agricultural Practices This standard describes the requirements for BiodiversityFriendly Agricultural Practices for the production of agricultural and fishery commodities in and around PAs and KBAs Likewise this standard provides a mechanism to define BiodiversityFriendly Agricultural Practices and when complied with it also enables producers to label their product accordingly However the standard does not cover procedures for verification such as inspection or certification of products
Through the ITPGRFA project the protocols for onfarm conservation of traditional varieties will be developed The basis for this protocol will be the available technical information in scientific literature as well as practices applicable to the community setting Other possible reference in drafting the said protocol are the good agricultural production and conservation practices which is biodiversity friendly observed during field studies and Community Field School
To date as a result of the study conducted by ITPGRFA project the information on the incentives for promotion of conservation as a result of the key informant interviews with producers market actors and institutional actors showed minimal incentives for promotion of traditional rice and root crops
The elements of the draft strategic action plan SAP for the conservation and sustainable use of traditional varieties of rice yam taro and sweet potato were identified through the preparatory phase stakeholder analysis and field studies in the six pilot barangays in the four provinces covered by the ITPGRFA project The elements of the SAP were identified and will be the basis of the draft that will be prepared

description.narrative: Systems and procedures for implementation of new regulations of trade in wild plant and animal resources

comment.narrative: Department Order issued
System established for surveillance monitoring and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals

The system being established for surveillance monitoring and mapping the sources of illegally traded wild plants and animals is in a form of partnerships with various national government agencies that are have mandates capabilities and procedures in detecting preventing and restricting illegal trade and transport of wildlife
The DENR together with the following agencies Department of the Interior and Local Government DILG Department of AgricultureBureau of Animal Industry DABAI Department of AgricultureBureau of Plant Industry DABPI Department of Trade and Industry Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board LTRFB Land Transportation Office LTO Maritime Industry Authority MIA Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines CAAB Civil Aeronautics Board CAB Philippine Coast Guard PCG Philippine Ports Authority PPA Light Rail Transit Authority LRTA Philippine National Railways PNR Philippine National Police PNP National Bureau of Investigation NBI Office for Transportation Security OTS Bureau of Customs BoC and National Prosecution Service NPS is in the process of creating an Interagency Committee Initial meetings have been carried out to fine tune the Memorandum of Agreement MoA providing for among other things the creation of the interagency committee and specifying the responsibilities of partner agencies
The BMB and BPPPMU successfully convened a consultation meeting with these agencies last April 7 2015 review the final draft of the MoA The final draft of the MoA is now being refined to incorporate the inputs solicited during this meeting

description.narrative: Systems policies tools and capacities for landscapelevel biodiversity conservation and sustainable development are applied at eight pilot sites covering at least 700000 hectares across five critical biogeographic regions Luzon Palawan NegrosPanay Mindoro Mindanao
Communities receiving incentives for shifting to sustainable practices

comment.narrative: Nil

Conservation agreements in place with at least two community groups in CPM and NNNP
PES schemes negotiated with two more community groups in other sites in PPLS and NNNP
10 communities engaged in sustainable livelihoods

The transboundary planning in CPM was deferred due to lack of interest of the LGUs to pursue the said planning The Project Management Unit PMU and Local Responsible Partner tried to convene for the Orientation Workshop on Transboundary Planning for Central Panay Mountains CPM the Provinces of Iloilo Antique Aklan and Capiz but only the Province of Iloilo was receptive thus the Orientation Workshop was pursued last July 1718 2014 for Iloilo however the succeeding workshops were not convened due to lack of interest and unavailability of the respective sectoral representatives to participate The conservation agreements in CPM however is covered in the Critical Habitat Declaration and Management Plan for instance goal number 3 in the proposed Critical Habitat Management Plan for Lambunao elaborate the sustainably manage human activities through communitybased resource management
In addition Conservation Agreement CAs are being done in Mt Hamiguitan in partnerships with the existing projects of Philippine Eagle Foundation The project provided
complementary support to the communitybased management of the Philippine Eagle Sanctuary by providing
funds for the pilottesting of a PublicPrivateCommunity PPC partnership through
Conservation Agreements CAs This
aims to provide forms of conservation
incentives to local communities who act
as managers of biodiversity areas and
have shown clear conservation outcomes
out of their management work In return the communities pledged to do
their share in conservation through
reforestation in their own farm lots
PES schemes in NNNP in partnership with the Provincial Environment and Management Office PEMO will still be identified
Around nine 9 peoples organizations communities are engaging in biodiversityfriendly livelihoods These are as follows
1 MASREDECA Matagaay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association in QPL
2 MPMC Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative in MSPLS
3 SIKAP Samahang Inaasahan ng mga Katutubo sa Alimanguan Palawan in MSPLS
4 PAFISFA Patag Farmers Integrated Social Foresty Association in NNNP
5 VISFA Victorias Integrated Social Forestry Association in NNNP
6 TIGMAMUGON Tigbobolo Mangunguma MangingisdaMamumugon Association Tigbobolo Bamboocraft Association Brgy Tigbobolo Culasi Antique in CPM
7 SJVPA Multipurpose Cooperative in Santiago San Jose Producers Association in Mainit Lake Mainit KBA
8 EPATLEA EcoPark AgriTourism Livelihood Enterprise Association n Kitcharao Lake Mainit KBA
9 LATAGG Lumad Almaciga Tappers Association of Gov Generoso in Mt Hamiguitan

description.narrative: Data and knowledge management systems to support local initiatives

comment.narrative:
Some LGUs have isolated data and knowledge management systems but not linked to national system
Insufficient data to adequately monitor status and trends in biodiversity and impacts of development programs

Rapid resource assessments completedupdated in eight project sites
Population estimates of critically endangered species in eight sites determined
Monitoring system in place to determine progress in meeting conservation plan objectives linked to knowledge management system
Increased public awareness and positive support to conservation efforts among local stakeholders
LGU level data and knowledge management system enhanced
LGU staff trained in use of data and knowledge management system
LGUs able to access and share data and information in national system

Rapid resource assessments in the eight sites were completed and ecological profiles were updated

Malampaya Sound Protected Landscape and Seascape
Based on the survey conducted on the Palawan forest turtle in So Maubog Bgy Alacalian Taytay Palawan 28 Palawan forest turtle were captured Out of 28 individuals there are 4 males 4 females and 20 are juvenile whereby the sexual characteristic is not yet differentiated The baseline photo identification survey of the critically endangered Irrawaddy Dolphin Orcaella brevirostris using Darwin software revealed that there are 47 individuals within Malampaya Sound through photo identification based on their dorsal fin
Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area
Based on the biodiversity assessment survey conducted in the municipalities covering the Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area two 2 Tarictic Hornbill Penelopides panini were sighted in Jabonga Agusan del Norte The presence of Manggachapui or dalingdingan Hopea acuminata one of the critically endangered species of flora are found in Jabonga Santiago Kitcharao While the Rafflesia mixta was found in Mainit Surigao del Norte A total of 7 Silvery Kingfisher Alcedo argentata six 6 Whitecollared Fruit Bat Megaerops wetmorei 21 Mindanao Horned Frog Megophrys stejnegeri and Mangkuno Xantostemon verdugonianus classified as vulnerable were recorded within Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area aside from these the almaciga Agathis philippinensis an endangered species were also found in Tubod Surigao del Norte
Drafted the Framework for the local biodiversity ME System LBMES
The design and manual for local biodiversity ME System LBMES for LGUs report on the pilottesting of the LBMES and Implementation Plan and enabling document for the installation and operationalization of the LBMES within DILG and the LGUs still ongoing
Continous advocacy and awareness activities in various forms eg exhibits knowledge products paper presentations on preliminary results of biodiversityfriendly businessenterprise in Convention on Biological Diversity Side Event in Pyeongchang Korea and Asean Social Forestry Network Conference for ASEAN Economic Community in Inle Lake Shan State Myanmar

description.narrative: Farmers adopting biodiversity friendly practices

comment.narrative: No increase over project period

At least 5000 farmers adopting biodiversity friendly agricultural practices
Additional 2000 farmers and producers meeting certification standards

About two 2 hectares of demonstration farm for biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices was established in Sitio Mahucdam Bgy Kapayaan Tubod Surigao Norte
The project provided assistance in the establishment of a demonstration farm covering around 217 hectares in Sitio Managaksak Brgy Sta Cruz Murcia Negros Occidental
Same assistance was provided to Brgy Eden Cabarroguis Quirino in the establishment of 22 9 hectares of demonstration farms following the biodiversityfriendly principles
Based on assessment using the biodiversityfriendly agricultural practices framework and principles about 893 farmers are practicing biodiversityfriendly agricultural practices
Completed profiles of additional model sites for biodiversityfriendly agriculture practices Conducted initial suitability assessment of the proposed modeldemonstration farm site in MSPLS in Palawan and in Mt Siburan in Sablayan Mindoro Occidental
The standards for biodiversityfriendly agricultural practices is still being finalized

description.narrative: Inter LGU cooperation in planning and regulation of natural resource use

comment.narrative:
Municipal and City LGUs plan separately and do not coordinate and harmonize their plans
Provincial Land Use Committees oversee and approves municipal and city land use plans
LGUs within PAs or KBAs do not jointly adopt any economic PES instruments

At least two transboundary conservation areas established
LGUs in the project sites at least 3 jointly managed landscapes harmonize their development plans for natural resource use in biodiversity landscapes that cut across their administrative boundaries
LGUs in the project sites sharing PA or KBA areas jointly adopt resource planning tools such as FLUP ICRMP ecological zoning
At least 3 Provincial CLUPs in the project sites adopt the planning tools for biodiversity conservation
PES instrument developed and tested in at least one biodiversity landscape

Two 2 Transboundary Conservation Areas will be established in Northeastern Cagayan Key Biodiversity Area NECKBA covering six 6 LGUs and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area LMKBA covering eight 4 LGUs each in Agusan and Surigao Del Norte
Protected Area Management Plan PAMP for Quirino Protected Landscape QPL is being enhanced and finalized The PAMP for Northern Negros Natural Park NNNP was enhanced
Taytay and San Vicente LGUs in Malampaya Sound Protected Landscapes jointly adopt the Forest Land Use Plan FLUP ICRMP and Environmental Critical Area Network ECAN Framework planning ECAN Framework planning was initiated by Palawan Council for Sustainable Development PCSD
Payment for Ecosystem Services PES instruments on Watershed Management and Water Systems were developed and pilottested in Quirino Protected Landscapes QPL

description.narrative: LGU development plans at project sites complying with SEA approach as well as landscape level natural resources management

comment.narrative:
LGUs do not apply SEAs in local development planning
PA management plans and FLUPs not integrated in CLUPs

At least 20 of LGUs in the project sites apply SEA in their development planning
At least 20 of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning PA or KBA zoning in their CLUP

As mentioned in Outcome 2 about 12 of the total LGUs covered by the project were given Orientation Training on simplified BDSEA Orientation will still be done to other LGUs
As per recommendation of the Midterm Evaluators and subject to GEF approval instead of 8 LGUs at least 20 of LGUs focal attention shall be provided to at least two 2 LGUs Accordingly this proposal will allow the BPPPMU to provide more time in finetuning delivery systems documentation of lessons learned and facilitating sharing and reflection among early practitioners of SEA The PMU will focus on Training and Coaching in the use of the simplified BDSEA for LGUs this 3rd and 4th quarter of 2015
56 of LGUs in the project sites integrate biodiversity conservation zoning PA or KBA zoning in their CLUP
Update on the mainstreaming work
CLUPs of LGUs in Quirino Protected Landscape and Lake Mainit Key Biodiversity Area were already approved
CLUP of Toboso is subject for review
CLUP of Buguey is subject to Public hearing
CLUP of Sta Teresita Baggao and Culasi are at the level of project prioritization
CLUP of Calatrava is for final writing
CLUP of Silay is under Options formulation
CLUP of Sebaste is at the level of Land Use policy formulation and sectoral studies
CLUP of Governor Generoso at the level of Land use policy and sectoral planning
San Isidro Davao Oriental Gattaran and Gonzaga Cagayan provided their reference materials for environment sector

description.narrative: New conservation areas established

comment.narrative: s
Three new conservation areas established covering 15 LGUs

Delineated 2 two new conservation areas as Local Conservation Areas in Tubod and Mainit Surigao Del Norte
Drafted ordinance declaring the municipalities of Alegria and Kitcharao as Local Conservation Areas
1 LGU Lambunao in Central Panay Mountains approved the Resolution declaring 231842 hectares as Critical Habitat this aim to conserve and protect the wildlife species within regulate the collection and trade of wildlife address the threats and effectively manage
1 LGU Sebaste in Central Panay Mountains drafted an Ordinance Providing for the Establishment of a Critical Habitat 2567hectares in the Municipality of Sebaste Province of Antique defining the Area of Coverage Creating Institutional Management Mechanisms Defining its Powers and Functions and for Other Purposes

description.narrative: Pressures from overharvesting of wild resources

comment.narrative: Expected to increase over total area of KBAsPAs in project sites by 10 each year

Pressure reduced in PAs totaling at least 260000 hectares
No net reduction in population of key species in selected sites
eg hornbill Philippine eagle etc

The policy on the guidelines for the harmonized implementation of regulations on the domestic trade in wildlife is still under review of the policy review committee of DENR
The protection and rehabilitation of remaining forests and wildlife habitats were included in the CLUPs and CDPs of LGUs that participated in the BD mainstreaming work
To reduced the pressure in Protected Areas totaling at least 260000 hectares the Local Government Units were encouraged to have an enhanced Local Environment Code LEC that elaborate the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act Republic Act No 9147 which states that LGUs shall initiate conservation measures for endemic species in their areas
To date the status of LEC preparations are as follows
1 LGU Calatrava with local ordinances Local Environment Code to support regulation of local endemics Ongoing preparation of Baggao Cagayan LEC
Two 2 LGUs Calatrava in NNNP and Baggao in NeCKBA have already conducted workshops for the preparation of Local Environment Code LEC that provide detail on regulation of local endemics under the Wildlife Resources Conservation and Protection Act Republic Act No 9147 while a LEC orientation was conducted for the remaining five 5 LGUs within NeCKBA
Two 2 LGUs Alegria Surigao Del Norte and Santiago Agusan Del Norte provided their existing Local Environment Code to Lake Mainit BPP team for assessment and further enhancement to include details on regulation of local endemics
Completed the Biodiversity Assessments in the eight 8 sites biodiversity monitoring will be done in 2016

comment.narrative: Nil

At least four businesses engaged in biodiversityfriendly enterprises in project sites by year 5
At least four producer groups in PAsKBAs adhere to LGU investor codes of conduct

Bakong Enterprise
Marine products in Buguey Cagayan
Quirino Ginger Tea Bamboo Coffee Banana and Cornstarch
Pandan leaves and bamboo small furnitures in Malampaya
Souvenir items production made of nito nipay seeds and tiger grass
Organic vegetables in Gawahon
Almaciga resin tapping in Mt Hamiguitan
Status to date
Ongoing ecological and feasibility study for the bakong enterprise
Ongoing feasibility study for marine products in Buguey Cagayan
Ongoing formulation of Cooperative systems and procedures for the Malampaya Pancol Multipurpose Cooperative MPMC
Memorandum of Agreement MoA signed with Mati City for the provision of funds to support expansion of almaciga resin production
To institutionalize and sustain support to the identified biodiversityfriendly business in the project sites various agreements with the private sectors peoples organizations and local consolidators are being finalized the status are as follows
Memoranda of Understanding between private sectors and Biodiversity Management Bureau are for signing the private sectors are as follows Association of Negros Producers and Freshstart Organics in Negros Occidental Antique Development Foundation in CPM
Tripartite MoU between Quirino Provincial Local Government Units QPLGU Philippine Coffee Alliance Inc and PCAI Matagaay Sustainable Resources Development and Conservation Association MASREDECA for signing
Tripartite Memorandum of Understanding MoU between DENR through BMB QPLGU and Bote Central for signing

None yet The project has just approved its first set of proposals The first proposals have big potential for starting out new landscapes At this point proposals are being developed using the landscape strategy The project has been in constant dialogue with local CSOs So far five potential landscapes have been identified 1 Northern Samar connecting the Samar Island National Park and the BiRi LaRosa Protected Seascape 3 the stretch of forests ancestral domains and coastal areas of San Luis up to Maria Aurora in Aurora Province 3 the environs of the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park which can serve as its buffer zone 4 the unprotected VictoriaAnepaan Mountain Range in southern Palawan and 5 the Mt CaraballoMt Palali ranges which connects Sierra Madre and Cordillera mountain ranges Sitebased consultations and project developments are in various stages
